Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Assessing the Role of Geologic Framework on Barrier Island Geomorphology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will quantitatively assess how subsurface geology impacts the beach and dunes along the coast, thereby helping to improve contemporary models of barrier island evolution. The project will contribute to more accurate predictions of how beaches and dunes are likely to change in the future due to sea-level rise. Understanding the influence of the subsurface geology will enable coastal managers to mitigate damage to infrastructure in areas where the subsurface geology promotes rapid change in the beach and dunes. Project results therefore will enable officials of the National Park Service and other managers to manage coastal resources at Padre Island National Seashore and elsewhere for long-term environmental and economic viability. The project will provide valuable professional development experience for an undergraduate student, and the project data and findings will be synthesized into a new coastal geography course module designed to provide students with a better understanding of how the subsurface geology controls change along the coast. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Rising sea-level and extreme storms can significantly erode the coast, damaging buildings and roads. Dunes have the ability to absorb strong waves and elevated water levels during extreme storms, which means it is important that coastal managers understand how the dunes may change in the future. Subsurface geology may affect how the beach and dunes change, but this link has not been tested. This project is to quantify the role of subsurface geologic framework in barrier island development and evolution. The doctoral student will test the hypothesis that the subsurface geologic framework is a key driver of coastal geomorphology. He will collect and analyze geophysical data using a range of techniques, including ground-penetrating radar, electromagnetic induction, and sub-bottom profiling along the entire length of Padre Island National Seashore on the southern Texas coast. Sediment cores will be collected along the island to provide essential information to correlate with data gathered using other means. The modern beach and dune morphology will be extracted from coastal digital elevation models based on light detection and ranging (LiDAR) measurements. Wavelet decomposition and coherence analyses will be used to quantify the influence of the subsurface geology on beach and dune morphology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Barrier islands are dynamic systems that change through time in response to natural and human factors. Many barrier islands migrate landward through time because of sand moved toward the mainland by storms and large waves. The purpose of this project was to better understand barrier island, beach, and dune formation was affected by the past landscape (now buried). While the project was focused on the entire ~100 km of Padre Island National Seashore (Texas, USA), the findings are translatable to a variety of coastal environments. Through a combination of geologic surveys, drone surveys, and computer programming, this research accurately mapped ancient river systems (now buried below the modern landscape) and documented how these systems influenced where the barrier island(s) formed and the size of coastal dunes. Because the data covered a very large area and was high volume, new computer models had to be developed to help process the large volumes of data and better understand the complex coastal landscape. The computer models show that ancient river systems can affect barrier island and dune size preferentially in one direction. These findings were validated by multiple layers evident in subsurface radar surveys collected along the beach, which show that the island was originally a series of separate islands. The separate islands coalesced by filling in preferentially from the north side of the ancient river valley to the south side of the valley. Although several thousand years have likely passed since the island coalesced, the impact of these ancient river systems on dune size is still apparent today. Because dunes cannot form on a surface until it is above the water, the island must have filled in an area before dunes could form in that same location. Dune height and crest elevation (maximum elevation of the dune) gradually increase from north to south within a given river valley. Dune height and crest elevation are very important factors when it comes to predicting the effect of storms and hurricanes on the coast because coastal dunes can provide a first line of defense against large waves that would otherwise damage or destroy coastal infrastructure and houses. Therefore, documenting directional patterns in the size of coastal dunes and identifying the underlying reasons for these patterns provides information vital to more efficient management of complex coastal environments.

 This research provided research and professional development opportunities for multiple undergraduate students. Approximately eight undergraduate students actively participated in all phases of the research process, including data collection and analysis. These students worked together in teams to tackle problems on the forefront of many fields. The Co-PI provided important mentorship for these students, many of whom had never collected data in the field, analyzed the data in the lab, and interpreted the data in context of the particular location. In addition to aiding in data collection and analysis, many of the undergraduate students utilized some of the data for side research projects, which they presented as oral papers and posters at 14 local, regional, and national conferences.

 With the impact of Hurricane Harvey along the Texas coast in August 2017, this research shifted focus slightly and expanded to better understand how the modern beach and dunes recover following Hurricane Harvey and how humans may affect this recovery. Using drones to collect elevation information along ~14 km of Padre Island National Seashore, this research continues to push the boundaries of large data to help managers, communities, and researchers more effectively allocate coastal resources. The impact of human activity on system recovery remains the focus of research in collaboration with the U.S. National Park Service and private industry.
